Wait, what? This is Amazing!

First impression:

Have to say i did not really consider this game when i first got a VR headset. I've played many of the major FPS's available on quest + Boneworks, Zero Caliber and Stormland with link, but left this one out. Until now. AND MAN! was i surprised 

This game, if you Even remotely like guns this is for you, you dont have to be a gun buff to get it either. What caught my eye was the perfect execution using GUNS in VR. A quest game with actual gun physics? Wow. Reloading Feels great, every aspect of adjusting weapons also feels natural. It reminds me alot of Pavlov's way of reloading interaction with guns + the physics side of Boneworks.

There's soooo many guns to choose from, both modern guns, WW2 and concept guns.
And every gun can have attachements, you can make some really funny looking guns maxing out on attachements. You can also but modern attachements on WW2 guns aswell. Plus the weapons can be upraded themselves both in capacit and, firepower

The game has several modes and levels with different styles of popup targets, some are moving towards you, some are static, some are shooting at you etc. You Will get rewarded for headshots, faster reloading etc.

There's also a Sandbox Mode, allowing you to test every gun and every attachement in the game, with a shooting range, and the ability to spawn every item in the game and place it wherever and target practice on.

Its all about making cash buying new weapons and unlocking new ones. Did i mention the graphics look great? Particularly the guns themselves have satisfying reflections and look like the real deal. This is only a first impression for me as I've only played it for a couple of hours. But its seems like there's alot of content here, levels and challenges with increased difficulty, also a creepy zombie mode with moving targets. Will definately keep me coming back 

I can safely recommend it!

A Solution/Fix for 2 Handed Weapons

Okay, so at first I gave this game 4 stars for 2 handed weapons being really inaccurate and unrealistic to real-life hands but I found out there is a setting to fix this.

Go to settings then find where it says "Stock Emulation" you want to turn that to off/disable and then you will have accurate 2 handed weapon feel that all VR shooters have.

I really don't know why the Devs put the setting on hybrid as default as at first I refunded the game because of the feel of holding 2 handed weapons to be very weird. However, I'm glad I bought the game again because ther are many settings you can enable to get a true VR range shooter like H3VR.

Guns are super realistic with every gun having it's own cocking mechanism and safety button and even different reloads. The actual addition to attachments is also what makes the game a time passer as I always come to the sandbox mode to just chill out and experiment with different weapons.

This game by no means is perfect but it's the nearest to H3VR when it comes to realism. As of right now there are about 50 weapons and 74 if you count the duplicates with different skins. I'm really hoping for a huge update where they can add at least 10 more weapons.

Overall, the game needs tweaking in the settings before playing but once you get everything configured then everything else will be a breeze and you'll find yourself coming back to this game a lot to pass time.

Also, this is a great game to show a first time VR user without them feeling nauseated and doing something too face paced. This is a must have especially for the price and if you are at all interested just a tiny bit in VR shooters then definitely add this to your library. Lastly, keep up the good work devs.

I was pleasantly surprised by how authentic they all look and operate, and there are a LOT of them, with a huge assortment of useful attachments and upgrades to put on them. SodaraptorJun 23 at 2:49 PM
Extremely solid and worth the price

Picked this up on the Quest as my first entry-level VR game and I can say with 100% certainty that it was worth the money.
If you're looking for a game that allows you to tinker with and shoot a varied amount of real-world guns, this is for you. There are tons of different scenarios for each category of weapon (pistol, SMG, shotgun, assault rifle, sniper rifle), each of which you play through in order to earn money to buy better guns or attachments. It's a mix of fun, no-frills shooting, and good accuracy/target practice that you'll see in other shooting games. I had the most fun shooting through waves in the zombie mode.
Some complaints I have stem mostly from the way the game handles the different "contact points" on each weapon. For example, I struggled a lot while using any rifle that had a charging handle near the barrel (such as the ACR or PSG-1), as every time I wanted to grab the grip, my VR hand would automatically snap to holding the charging handle instead. Some of the modes require quick reflexes, and you have to be able to reload pretty fast, so you can imagine how annoying this can be.
Another serious issue is that while upgrading weapons, a lot of the time you are told you "can't use this attachment because you don't have any rails", but my weapon CLEARLY has multiple open rails on it. For example, try attaching a rail onto the PSG-1, then try buying a bipod grip to put there. It will not let you, unless you buy the grip for another rifle, then spawn it, and manually attach it to the PSG-1.
Aside from those glaring issues, I still highly recommend this game for anyone with a Quest!

noah.lugeonsMar 29 at 12:35 PM
Really Glitchy

The gun mechanics are great in this game, but that's all it has going for it, and considering the myriad problems with the game, it seems silly to bother pointing that out.

So here are a couple of red flags that leave me surprised that this game is even for sale on the Oculus Store:

1 - The headset runs hot if you play this game for more than ten minutes or so.
2 - This game drains the battery at least three times quicker than any other game I've played.
3 - If you put the headset in sleep mode and set it aside while this game is running, the headset continues to run hot and drain batteries as quickly as if you were playing.
4 - The in-game boundary that you set up to indicate your play area DOES NOT APPEAR in this game, making it unsafe. Sure, you don't move around much in the game, but if you play any game for long, you drift a bit.

These are the most egregious problems with the game, but there are numerous other signs of poor programming or a desire to rush a half finished game to market. The shotguns often lose track of how many shells are in them. If you load and fire too fast they'll show as empty even if you just slid six shells into them. The 'you shot the wrong target' sound effect often comes up for no reason in the middle of the game'. A target you're supposed to hit occasionally shows up behind one you're not supposed to hit. The graphic that shows you the hit points of the target often obscures other targets, making certain challenges impossible on certain run throughs.

And even where there aren't glitches, there are plenty of problems. There's not much to do in the game to begin with, the sniper rifle challenges are both boring and confusing, you find yourself fighting with the game to get it to see which part of the gun you're trying to grab sometimes...

All in all, it's a good proof of concept, but not a good game. I'd love to see those same gun mechanics translated to another game, but this game needs a serious overhaul.

Of course the real reason to grind through these levels is earning money to buy new guns. But from a gameplay perspective, they're all mostly the same thing. In fact, pistols tend to be better than larger guns, so the best strategy is just buying a cheap pistol and using that for every level.

Unless you're a gun enthusiast and enjoy unlocking new guns for the look and sound, you'll quickly reach a point where neither new guns nor new levels are much motivation to keep playing, since in both cases they offer nothing new. What the devs have done is actually a pretty simple solution, the second your hand is holding a gun the in-game position of the gun is raised about 2 inches from where you're actual hand position is, so when you cokk (spellling change - thanks oculus) the pistol you go to grab just above where the real-world tracking ring is. The problem however is when this is applied to two handed weapons which makes aiming and looking down the sight feel off and unnatural. Developer ResponseAug 4, 2019 at 5:17 PM

The TS12 has some unique operations that we have tried to replicate. It can be reloaded like the other shell fed shotuns. Grab shells from your ammo bag and bring them near the rear of the shell tubes ( near the trigger group ) Press the interact button ( A or X ) to load individual shells into the tubes. When a tube is full pressing interact again will rotate to another tube to fill that one.
